ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a great deal about Islamic and Jewish medieval philosophy. I improved my essay-writing skills. I improved my seminar participation skills.
I learned a ton about Maimonides and Al-Ghazali. I also advanced in my ability to understand complex philosophical concepts.

I learned so much in this course. From the basics of Islamic philosophy and history to the intricate ties between al-Ghazali and Maimonides, and more amazing thinkers. And Prof. Griffel is amazing! I'm so glad I took this course

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course was perfect; well-structured, engaging, sufficiently challenging. Discussions were great, the instructors encouraged quality over quantity in essays. I felt that I improved my skills by the end of the course. Maps were fun! No complaints.

I think the readings for the course were well-arranged and consistently fascinating. I loved when in class we focused on smaller pieces of the primary texts and could analyze them in greater depth  the more we could do that, the better, to me.

all strengths for me. Professor Griffel has an image and plan for the entire semester and then carefully executes it to give his students an actual experience of building up knowledge and connecting dots. (in this way, definitely on the more structured side, so might want to consider if that's your thing). He gives a lot of personal feedback and has open office hours and is always happy to chat.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to any philosophy, humanities or religious studies major, or anyone interested in the history of the Islamic world, or anyone interested in the middle ages.

I would if the subject matter seems interesting to you. It was an incredible opportunity to learn in a small seminar with Professor Griffel you just absorb so much knowledge from him every single class so if that knowledge seems appealing, definitely take the class.
yes absolutely! you will learn so much and think so hard in such amazing ways!
